course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Education and Society
course.description: The course will initiate a sociologically informed conversation about formal education. What social and organizational forces have shaped current educational practices, and how can they be reformed? How does schooling perpetuate inequalities? Why do boys perform so poorly compared to girls in schools? How can ethnic minorities be better served in educational systems? What is the role of the humanities and creativity in education? Why do people now question the value of higher education? What is the future of education? To answer these questions, students will be encouraged to reflect upon their own educational experiences, read sociological accounts of education and participate in contemporary debates about education at all levels in Hong Kong and across cultures.

reviews.author: yytsui
reviews.title: Interesting Sociology Course
reviews.comment_content:
Personally, the social issues about education sound interesting to me. Some of the issues may be global issues, while some may also relate to ourselves as a college student in Hong Kong.

Abstract sociological concepts are brought to students through examples from lectures and readings, which makes those terms and concepts easier to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Groves is one of the best instructors I've met in UST. He is willing to answer to students' questions and he encourages students to discuss with each other in class. The learning atmosphere is quite good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grades if you attend the lectures. (though no attendance is taken, up to 10% extra credit may be awarded to individual students who
make regular and outstanding contributions to the in-class discussions, or who frequently ask
relevant questions)

The instructor also explained the readings in class, so even if you have not finished all the readings, you can still catch up in class.
reviews.comment_workload:
Required readings for each lecture, which will be posted on Canvas.
The workload for the project is not that heavy if you have chosen the right groupmates.

reviews.author: H_Barnes
reviews.title: A course requiring a great effort to study
reviews.comment_content: Formal education analyzed in sociological terms, inequalities, ethnic minorities, etc. Its range is quite broad: e.g. debates in education at all levels from Hong Kong to across different countries. With a broad but in-depth analysis, it makes you learn quite a lot in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Groves encourages discussions and student participations in class. The more you take part in, the more credit can be obtained towards counting the final grade. But this requires quite an effort to catch up with the class, by reading the weekly assignments frequently and thoroughly, for example. You can hardly catch up with the class nor even learn a thing in class if you do not study the weekly reading assignments or revise the materials taught in the lecture.
But Groves' teaching is quite interesting in a sense that he tells some jokes in class to draw your attention and plays some videos on Youtube. This is at least more interesting than those mundane "non-interacting" lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair. Below mean --> C range
Mean --> B range
The mean for midterm or final exam is quite high (around 60~70 /100) so it is not very easy to obtain a good result unless you revise the topics comprehensively. The questions in the exams are somewhat straight forward. If you understand the meaning/reason/background behind those topics, then the exams are easy to handle. Also paying attention in the lectures is a good practice because it helps understand the materials taught quite a lot. So doing the above can easily get a good grade (for hard-working students).
reviews.comment_workload:
As said, this course requires quite a effort to read the very-long-and-full-of-words materials. Unless you are a veteran in sociology and educations, you will find this course quite hard.
A project in a group of 5-7 people is required in topics like ethnic minorities and hidden curriculum, etc. Students in a group will need to co-write a 10-page essay to be submitted within a month. Dr. Groves will select some well-performed groups to give a presentation.
All these things are quite heavy workload. Lazy people (especially those who do not study for exams, "裸考"), or those without a great interest in education are not advised to take this course LOL.

reviews.author: aduhuda
reviews.title: A very fun and rewarding course
reviews.comment_content:
The whole class coverage is actually pretty broad but it all ties together in the end and gives a pretty interesting outlook of the education system in Hong Kong and also the world. (Check out the syllabus).

I think the course content is designed quite well. Each class topic is not necessarily related to one another, but there are common important ideas to remember between topics.

The PPTs are really helpful to review the overall topics, but the readings are actually the main full content, so you definitely need to do both to understand completely.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Groves is the most chill professor ever. He showed us so many documentaries and also youtube videos that sometimes take up almost more than half of the class time. He would have 5-10 mins breaks in the middle of the class just for us to stretch. But despite that, he's able to explain the concepts clearly and giving us everyday examples that are easy to digest. He also has really cute cats that he sometimes shows to class. Definitely my top 3 profs in UST.
reviews.comment_grading:
I personally think the grading is quite good.

Grades:
9/10 -> Assignment 25% (mean = 8.68, SD = 0.53)
30.5/32 -> Midterm 35% (mean = 25.21, SD = 4.61)
29/35 -> Final 40% (mean = 26.34, SD = 5.95)
I spoke up at least 1x in every class and presented my assignment at the last class -> Up to 5% extra credit for participation
= got A
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite chill as long as you catch up with the content every week. Doing the readings before class is definitely a must because it complements the learning process and it is the only way that you can contribute meaningfully in class. The readings even tho quite long are actually really fun and insightful in my opinion. And also go to class so you can earn the participation points and catch up with the weekly contents.

If you do the above, then you only probably need to revise 1 or 2 days before the midterm and finals (that's what I did).

For this semester because everything is online, the assignment was just individual work and it was really a light workload considering the 25% weighting. It can be done in 1 or 2 productive days as well.

reviews.author: Alvin yu
reviews.comment_content: Content is good, the lesson talks about the relationship between education and different aspect of society such as gender, racing, social class and ethnicity.
reviews.comment_teaching: The PPT is quite attractive as it's in point form and sometimes there are short videos, so do long the one. If you are not good in English, it might be tight to you to look at the long video. However, it's fine that even your English is not very native.
reviews.comment_grading: my mid-term lower than mean 1sd, project higher than mean~1-2 sd, final was also higher than mean 1sd. I got a C+
reviews.comment_workload: The project is quite interesting. We have to get into a middle class/working class secondary school and see what is the relationship between the teaching method and social class

reviews.author: Gampy
reviews.title: Good Teaching....but fair grading
reviews.comment_content:
If you are interested in learning education -related materials, you will definitely love this course.
Themes include:
1. Labeling Effects
2. Education and Social Class
3. Education and Gender
4. Hong Kong Education
5. Issues in Higher Education
6. Progressive Education
All of them are quite interesting, and there are readings/ videos/ ppt slides about the theme.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Interactive teaching, and the slides are well-prepared as well.
Good classroom management and students love to discuss with him after class.
Strong British accent which may be a bit hard for some local students to catch up.
A little break of 5~10 minutes is given in each class, which could let students to rest.
No computer/ mobile device could be used in the lecture, may be quite harsh to some students.
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance has to be taken, but since each lecture got a heavy content, better ask friends to help jot down notes.
Grading is not too satisfactory, even you get high score, it is hard to get A or A+.

Grading policy (not very sure) :
Group Project 25% (topics can be chosen freely from Social Class/ Ethnic minorities/ HKUST as a university)
Mid-term 35% (include topic 1~3)
Final 40% (include topic 1~6)
10% additional credits given for class participation/ extra voluntary presentation of the group project

Group project my group get 24/25
Both mid term and final higher than the class mean for more than 1 sd,
but I still only get an A- ...not too satisfactory as I think I have already done some of the class participation

The exams are quite easy (you can score about 90% if you have finished all the readings and powerpoint, some of the questions are just common sense)
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite large in terms of readings, studying powerpoint slides, and group project

Each week 1 ~15 pages reading is expected, it is easy if you could finish it each week, but the review is still quite grueling.

Project is relatively easy, just a 10-page short project is needed for a team of 4 students.

reviews.author: iwantarange
reviews.title: Paying attention in class guarantees a B range
reviews.comment_content:
Before midterm: More about sociological concepts like correspondence principle, labeling theory, hidden curriculum
After midterm: Applying sociological concepts into current education system, ranging from HK higher education system to the Finnish system. To be exact, I would just quote some guided questions in the syllabus that I received at the first class.

The course will initiate a sociologically informed conversation about education.What is school for?What social forces have shaped our current educational practices? Does schooling provide new opportunities, or perpetuate old inequalities? How are ethnic minorities marginalized from education systems? Why do boys perform so poorly compared to girls in our schools? What should be the role of the humanities and creativity in education? Why is there a “crisis” in higher education?How might education be reformed?To answer these questions, we will study a number of important sociological works on education and you will be encouraged to reflect upon your own educational experiences, as well as examine contemporary debates about education at all levels in Hong Kong, and across cultures.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is quite good and he is very willing to help any students who cannot follow. It is worth-mentioning that there will be additional office hours just before the midterm and final exam. He will give some hints about the content of the exam, so do take advantage of that. Do try that even if you are good enough as it certainly will boost your score.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 35%
Project 25%
Final exam 40%
Optional: Up to 10% extra credits for participation

As Prof Groves mentioned during the class, most students attending the lectures regularly and paying attention during the class won't find his exams difficult, so you can expect many students would get a decent score.
Overall, my course total is around 83.4% and got a B. The average is around 76.2% (not including the 10% extra credits), so I would not regard this course as a 'good grade' course. It may not be a good idea to take it if you are not good in social science as it is hard for you to get the 10% extra credits. Take myself as an example, I have tried hard to attempt the questions during the class, but I found that I couldn't even answer a lot because I can't really follow the class.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not heavy. Although you are required to do substantial amount of readings frequently (ie 2 times per week, same as the frequency of lessons), you may try to omit it and pay more attention during the class as Prof Groves will have a brief discussion on most of the readings.
A group project is required for this course. Nevertheless, you do not need to pay a lot of effort in order to finish it if there is no 'free-riders' in your group.

reviews.author: Noa
reviews.title: Interesting but Tough
reviews.comment_content: A lot of analyzing of social trends in education, the formation of out modern education system and its flaws, and some interesting theories about the subject. A lot of words, no math, and the topics are honestly very interesting and make you think about your society on a deeper level.
reviews.comment_teaching: The content is very interesting and he encourages discussion and interaction. However, if you are not seriously well versed in English, you will have a tough time, as he uses specialist terms fairly often and you need to understand the context well to make sense of it all. He is also very helpful in office hours and will give hints about the exams, so take advantage of that!
reviews.comment_grading: Getting a one SD above mean in all assignments and if you participate well he will give you an A. Getting 1.5 to two SD's above is guaranteed A+ if you participate well. I'm not too sure about the rest but mean is likely B range. Participation is crucial as it can make or break your grade. He is a fair grader and your effort corresponds to your grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
-10 page coauthored essay that takes ALOT of field work, so expect to spend at least 3 weekend days researching and interviewing people depending on your assignment.
- Assigned reading ever week (think around 3-6 full pages) which is very very dense. If you don't read it before class you will be lost, so please do.
- One easy final exam which is pretty easy to do well in if you have done your readings and paid attention in class. Its MC on general topics and not too specific
